text: Not sure if anyone is interested, but we just tweeted our first demo of Storyscript’s NLP to new Code <https://twitter.com/StoryscriptHQ/status/1242469802309857286> — Thank you!

text: PS don’t look TOO much into the actual code, this was a marketing demo which stripped it down. Here is, more or less, the real code.

text: Looks cool <@UJKKBAMLL>! Do you write code in Storyscript or a phrase like the video shows?

elements.text: Looks cool
! Do you write code in Storyscript or a phrase like the video shows?

text: Thank you! You can do both for sure. It’s more a wysiwig than an IDE. NLP is only to help you get the basics started by just having a dialog with the computer.

elements.text: Thank you! You can do both for sure. It’s more a wysiwig than an IDE. NLP is only to help you get the basics started by just having a dialog with the computer.

text: If anyone has a specific idea of what they want to see in Storyscript I can wip it up pretty quick. Just let me know :smile_cat:

text: the time is ripe for revisiting speech input for code—glad to see you’ve taken a shot at it!!

elements.text: the time is ripe for revisiting speech input for code—glad to see you’ve taken a shot at it!!

text: Very cool

elements.text: Very cool

text: I agree Brian.  We tackle this from many sides at the same time. NLP, abstraction, serverless, deployless, and wysiwyg UI builder kits.

elements.text: I agree Brian.  We tackle this from many sides at the same time. NLP, abstraction, serverless, deployless, and wysiwyg UI builder kits.

text: I would say that NLP to Python, for example, does not solve infra/deploy/server issues. So the key here is higher abstraction + NLP.

elements.text: I would say that NLP to Python, for example, does not solve infra/deploy/server issues. So the key here is higher abstraction + NLP.

text:
This is great, Steve. This demo reminded me a bit of Fantastical, and I think this _small, one statement at a time_ style of NLP is a great fit for the problem domain you're talking about right now (connecting other services together) (I say "talking about right now" because I'm assuming you've got bigger plans for the future, too).

This seems like the sort of feature that'd lend itself really well to a playground on your website — write some NL code, see what it gets parsed into. Any plans for a public interactive demo like that?

elements.text: This is great, Steve. This demo reminded me a bit of Fantastical, and I think this
small, one statement at a time

style of NLP is a great fit for the problem domain you're talking about right now (connecting other services together) (I say "talking about right now" because I'm assuming you've got bigger plans for the future, too).

This seems like the sort of feature that'd lend itself really well to a playground on your website — write some NL code, see what it gets parsed into. Any plans for a public interactive demo like that?

text:
Thank you Ivan! Yes, indeed this is a very small step in our journey. Our mission is much bolder.
We do plan to have an interactive, public, demo and live development straight on the website. It’s just going to take some time before we invite people publicly. We are hand-holding customers, one-by-one for quite some time before GA.

elements.text:
Thank you Ivan! Yes, indeed this is a very small step in our journey. Our mission is much bolder.
We do plan to have an interactive, public, demo and live development straight on the website. It’s just going to take some time before we invite people publicly. We are hand-holding customers, one-by-one for quite some time before GA.

text: Not showing in the demo is our collaboration tools, community, sharing, FE, debugging, data layer and embedded library. We just focused on NLP in this demo only.

elements.text: Not showing in the demo is our collaboration tools, community, sharing, FE, debugging, data layer and embedded library. We just focused on NLP in this demo only.

text: <@UJKKBAMLL>, is there something in Storyscript forcing versioning of the NLP model? If the NLP parses a phrase certain way today is there any way to ensure that it will be parsed the same way in the future?

elements.text: , is there something in Storyscript forcing versioning of the NLP model? If the NLP parses a phrase certain way today is there any way to ensure that it will be parsed the same way in the future?

text: Good question. Maybe there is some confusion however. The NL is not the source of truth: the resulting code is. The code will work always with versioning in mind, it won’t break when the NLP gets smarter. So it goes. The goal of the NLP is to _assist_ users in developing complex business-logic but is *not* the only way to do it. You can of course still write code (with auto-completing, strong-type, yadda yadda). The NLP demos well and sets the tone of the product; but in the long term will be a source of creation and interaction with the user like never seen before.

elements.text: Good question. Maybe there is some confusion however. The NL is not the source of truth: the resulting code is. The code will work always with versioning in mind, it won’t break when the NLP gets smarter. So it goes. The goal of the NLP is to
assist

not

the only way to do it. You can of course still write code (with auto-completing, strong-type, yadda yadda). The NLP demos well and sets the tone of the product; but in the long term will be a source of creation and interaction with the user like never seen before.

text: Let’s say today, we can take a block of NL and generate only 1% code. Tomorrow 2%. Next year 20%. Then, the tipping point, and you have users that simply ask the computer to build stuff and it does it; leaving you with holes to fill in (because NL is full of holes)

text: <@U85HCL7JP> Thank you and let me know if that answered the question :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Thank you and let me know if that answered the question

text: Thanks for the response, yes it does answer the question

elements.text: Thanks for the response, yes it does answer the question

text: That also solidifies things for me, too. FWIW, the demo definitely gave me the impression that the code is the source of truth, and the NLP is just a convenient/friendly way to generate the code with machine assistance. (Thus the Fantastical reference, since they take a very similar approach to working with calendar events.)

elements.text: That also solidifies things for me, too. (Thus the Fantastical reference, since they take a very similar approach to working with calendar events.)

text: wow <@UJKKBAMLL>, storyscript has come a long way in the past few months! great job to you and the team! i'm curious: does the natural language input "stick around" anywhere in the code once it's translated into your scripting language? would be nice to keep it in there as a kind of "dynamic comment"

elements.text: wow

, storyscript has come a long way in the past few months! great job to you and the team! i'm curious: does the natural language input "stick around" anywhere in the code once it's translated into your scripting language? would be nice to keep it in there as a kind of "dynamic comment"

text:
A few thoughts:
• the language translation UX feels right. It makes everything feel more approachable because it knows what you mean. But then again, sometimes it’s more confusing because you don’t even know what you want — you just want to explore. Have you tried using the Emvi experimental UI? It’s super cool, but you feel blind. You have to know what you want to do as soon as you open it.
•  I’m more excited for the whole system you’re building — it sounds like the programming toolkit of every modern-day humans’ dreams. It has got me thinking... The whole “no code” space is going the direction of making something like excel more powerful like programming. But what about the other direction? Maybe you could make a well-crafted typescript library for all of this. You can use the Monaco editor with prettier, eslint and js doc strings. It could be incredibly approachable for the beginner-level JavaScript programmer with auto-complete and popup documentation. They don’t have to worry about deployment or anything. Makes me think of a cross between Mathematica and SmallTalk.
Anyways, interest to see where you go with this!

elements.text: A few thoughts:

the language translation UX feels right. It makes everything feel more approachable because it knows what you mean. But then again, sometimes it’s more confusing because you don’t even know what you want — you just want to explore. Have you tried using the Emvi experimental UI? It’s super cool, but you feel blind. You have to know what you want to do as soon as you open it.

I’m more excited for the whole system you’re building — it sounds like the programming toolkit of every modern-day humans’ dreams. It has got me thinking... The whole “no code” space is going the direction of making something like excel more powerful like programming. But what about the other direction? Maybe you could make a well-crafted typescript library for all of this. You can use the Monaco editor with prettier, eslint and js doc strings. It could be incredibly approachable for the beginner-level JavaScript programmer with auto-complete and popup documentation. They don’t have to worry about deployment or anything. Makes me think of a cross between Mathematica and SmallTalk.
Anyways, interest to see where you go with this!
